# litterfitter ![](reference/figures/litterfitter_hex.png)

> R package for fitting and testing alternative models for single cohort
> litter decomposition data

### Installation

``` r
  #install.packages("remotes")
  remotes::install_github("cornwell-lab-unsw/litterfitter")
  
library(litterfitter)
```

### Getting started

At the moment there is one key function which is `fit_litter` which can
fit 6 different types of decomposition trajectories. Note that the
fitted object is a `litfit` object

``` r
fit <- fit_litter(time=c(0,1,2,3,4,5,6),
                  mass.remaining =c(1,0.9,1.01,0.4,0.6,0.2,0.01),
                  model="weibull",
                  iters=500)

class(fit)
```

You can visually compare the fits of different non-linear equations with
the `plot_multiple_fits` function:

``` r
plot_multiple_fits(time=c(0,1,2,3,4,5,6),
                   mass.remaining=c(1,0.9,1.01,0.4,0.6,0.2,0.01),
                   model=c("neg.exp","weibull"),
                   iters=500)
```

![](reference/figures/README-unnamed-chunk-4-1.png)

Calling `plot` on a `litfit` object will show you the data, the curve
fit, and even the equation, with the estimated coefficients:

``` r
   plot(fit)
```

![](reference/figures/README-unnamed-chunk-5-1.png)

The summary of a `litfit` object will show you some of the summary
statistics for the fit.

``` R
#> Summary of litFit object
#> Model type: weibull 
#> Number of observations:  7 
#> Parameter fits: 4.19 
#> Parameter fits: 2.47 
#> Time to 50% mass loss: 3.61 
#> Implied steady state litter mass: 3.71 in units of yearly input 
#> AIC:  -3.8883 
#> AICc:  -0.8883 
#> BIC:  -3.9965
```

From the `litfit` object you can then see the uncertainty in the
parameter estimate by bootstrapping

![](reference/figures/README-unnamed-chunk-7-1.png)

# Package index

## All functions

- [`bootstrap_parameters()`](http://traitecoevo.github.io/litterfitter/reference/bootstrap_parameters.md)
  : Create a bootstrap distribution of a particular coefficient from a
  model fit
- [`fit_litter()`](http://traitecoevo.github.io/litterfitter/reference/fit_litter.md)
  : Fit different models to single cohort decomposition data
- [`litterfitter-package`](http://traitecoevo.github.io/litterfitter/reference/litterfitter.md)
  [`litterfitter`](http://traitecoevo.github.io/litterfitter/reference/litterfitter.md)
  : litterfitter: methods for fitting curves to litter decomposition
  trajectories
- [`pineneedles`](http://traitecoevo.github.io/litterfitter/reference/pineneedles.md)
  : decomposition trajectory for pine needles
- [`plot(`*`<litfit>`*`)`](http://traitecoevo.github.io/litterfitter/reference/plot.litfit.md)
  : Plot Decomposition Trajectory and Curve Fit
- [`plot(`*`<litfit_bootstrap>`*`)`](http://traitecoevo.github.io/litterfitter/reference/plot.litfit_bootstrap.md)
  : Plot the bootstrap distribution for a parameter from a litfit object
- [`plot_multiple_fits()`](http://traitecoevo.github.io/litterfitter/reference/plot_multiple_fits.md)
  : Plot multiple fits on one graph with model selection results
  displayed
- [`predict(`*`<litfit>`*`)`](http://traitecoevo.github.io/litterfitter/reference/predict.litfit.md)
  : Predict method for litfit objects
- [`steady_state()`](http://traitecoevo.github.io/litterfitter/reference/steady_state.md)
  : Estimate Steady State Biomass
- [`time_to_prop_mass_remaining()`](http://traitecoevo.github.io/litterfitter/reference/time_to_prop_mass_remaining.md)
  : Get the predicted time until half mass loss for a litter
  decomposition trajectory

# Articles

### All vignettes

- [litterfitter](http://traitecoevo.github.io/litterfitter/articles/litterfitter.md):
